# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Sure, I'll solve this problem by following your steps. Here is the code:
```julia
using DataFrames
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df2 = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df)
    model_values = ["a4", "a4 quattro"]
    df2[:audi_a4_type] = map(x-> x in model_values, df2.model)
    return df2
end
```
Firstly, I create a new DataFrame `df2` that only contains rows where the manufacturer is "audi". Then I use the map function to create a new column `audi_a4_type`, which will be equal to true if the model of the car is either "a4" or "a4 quattro", and false otherwise. Finally, this updated DataFrame `df2` is returned.

You can run this code in your Julia environment:
```julia
df = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df = audi_filter(df)
```
Then you can view the updated DataFrame:
```julia
println(df)
```
This will print out your updated DataFrame.
